New issue

String#underscore doesn't convert spaces to underscores #4519

Closed
shtirlic opened this Issue Jan 18, 2012 · 20 comments

Labels

None yet

Milestone

No milestone

Assignee

No one assigned

6 participants

shtirlic commented Jan 18, 2012

Why Rails String#underscore doesn't convert spaces to underscores?
The same is for String#camelize why it doesn't convert spaces to nothing?
Is there something behind it or I am missing the point?

1.9.3-p0 :001 > "Hello World".underscore
 => "hello world"
1.9.3-p0 :002 > "HelloWorld".underscore
 => "hello_world"

1.9.3-p0 :004 > "hello_world".camelize
 => "HelloWorld"
1.9.3-p0 :005 > "hello world".camelize
 => "Hello world"
Owner
fxn commented Jan 18, 2012

underscore is defined to give you a path (think file names) out of a Ruby constant name. Any other use cases are left undefined, you cannot rely on them.

shtirlic commented Jan 18, 2012

That's sad because if method says underscore it should underscore, it's also true for camelize

Owner
fxn commented Jan 18, 2012

Agreed, from Foo::BarBaz you get "foo/bar_baz" and that's it, but the method name sounds more generic.

It has to be said, though, that at least it is well-documented, see http://guides.rubyonrails.org/active_support_core_extensions.html#underscore

shtirlic commented Jan 18, 2012

Ok, so there is no chance for Pull Request this, right?

pokonski commented Jan 18, 2012

This is more of an internal function, a lot of changing what be involved (unless I'm very mistaken).

shtirlic commented Jan 18, 2012

@pokonski it's not possible to have spaces in ruby for names AFAIK, so it's not a problem.

pokonski commented Jan 18, 2012

@shtirlic but you wanted to use underscore for something else than creating file names, I believe?

Owner
fxn commented Jan 18, 2012

That's correct, Ruby accepts spaces in other weird places, like symbols or method names, but constant names do not allow them.

shtirlic commented Jan 18, 2012

@pokonski yep, I use underscore in before filters for attributes in AR models to format values entered by the user and my current workaround is like this:

def format_name
  self.name.gsub!(/( )/, '_').downcase!
end

Also I don't know anyone who likes spaces in file or directory names.

Owner
fxn commented Jan 18, 2012

@pokonski do you know parameterize? http://guides.rubyonrails.org/active_support_core_extensions.html#parameterize

pokonski commented Jan 18, 2012

@fxn, Yes I do :) I'm fine with having hyphens.

Owner
fxn commented Jan 18, 2012

Cool... do you think we can close this issue?

shtirlic commented Jan 18, 2012

@fxn I think this was for me.
arrgh!! I can use it now like this and it solves my problem.

1.9.3-p0 :005 > "John Smith".parameterize.underscore
 => "john_smith"
shtirlic closed this Jan 18, 2012
Owner
fxn commented Jan 18, 2012

Arrghhh sorry, the question about parameterize was meant to be for @shtirlic :).

Owner
fxn commented Jan 18, 2012

@shtirlic awesome!

shtirlic commented Jan 18, 2012

Thank you both. Will try to "combine" methods harder in the future and don't spam rails issues ʘ‿ʘ

pokonski commented Jan 18, 2012

@shtirlic you can always ask in mail groups :)

And that's a scary looking emoticon :O

rhamlin commented Oct 14, 2014

Just got bit by this "bug". Although it was easy to hunt down, and correct, I've got to say I don't believe this is the direction that was decided, and what's even more bothering is: it was accepted. .underscore provides paths derived from Ruby constants...yeah, that makes sense. Documented or not, this is not an optimal implementation in Rails and should be changed.

thenonsequitur commented Nov 23, 2015

.parameterize.underscore works, but you can also do .parameterize('_')

nroose commented Dec 22, 2015

@thenonsequitur nice!
